habitat_description:
Northwest/Southwest:
Brush rabbits are found from the Columbia River to the Mexican border in western Oregon and California. They inhabit dense, brushy edges of early successional oak and conifer, as well as chapparal, grazing on grasses and forbs within grasslands, meadows and riparian areas (Polite et al. based on Zeiner et al. 1990, NatureServe 2013). It ranges in elevation up to approximately 2070 meters (Chapman 1974). In the Willamette Valley, this species is found within disjunct clumps of brambles > 460 m2 (especially blackberry and sweet briar) scattered among forbs and grasses (quoted directly from Verts and Carraway 1998). Along the Columbia River, the brush rabbit has been found in communities dominated by beachgrass, sitka spruce, black cottonwood, and willow (Hinschberger 1978, Verts and Carraway 1998). In coastal areas, Verts and Carrway (1998) report having observed this species in bush lupine.
